Author: ITrCool

Comment: After Trump's comments on Canada, which are not going over well with Canadian voters, the election is not going to give an accurate read of where Canadians are on the right-left spectrum; however they vote, I would assume that the result is probably going to be skewed leftward by Trump, so their actual sentiments are more rightward than the results.  Poilievre is not a fan of Trump, and he has [actively discouraged Trump from commenting on the election](https://thehill.com/policy/international/5271654-pierre-poilievre-trump-canada/), which is probably a sign that he knows Trump's comments are hurting him. The pull or influence of someone like Trump is big though, in a way that I think Americans are sometimes not able to appreciate. A large portion of Canadian voters (I have heard from some) equate Poilievre with Trump and a significant portion of these voters may vote Liberal in part out of spite against Trump.  There things I don't like about Poilievre, but they don't have anything to do with his relationship to Trump. He is pro-union and pro-minimum wage, two views I disagree with. He also opposes carbon tax (which I support, I like market-based approaches to environmental issues, and I like that the revenue from carbon tax can offset other more damaging taxes like income or payroll tax) and instead he adopts more management-intensive and restrictive approaches to energy and environmental issues, like he has supported a import ban on foreign oil, which is an anti-free-trade and anti-free-market intervention that I oppose. Overall though, I think Poilievre is a much better candidate than Trump and if I were given the choice of the two to lead either company, I would pick Poilievre without much thought; not only are his views closer to mine overall, but I think he's smarter and more competent, better able to represent a constituency, and just a more reasonable, balanced person.  I'm not Canadian though so it's a moot point.

Comment: I wouldn't be surprised at 60-40 for Liberals when the votes come. It's a great move by the left; don't let the people look at their real situation or the reason they're overtaxed and overburdened with regulations, blame America so that people can be distracted with a fake issue, rather than a real one.    When Conservatives point out that America isn't the problem, Liberals call them names or unpatriotic, and claim they're just shills for the US, and use their own compliant media to shut the conversation down.
